paper_abstract: In many real-world tasks, there are abundant unlabeled examples but the number of labeled training examples is limited, because labeling the examples requires human efforts and expertise. So, semi-supervised learning which tries to exploit unlabeled examples to improve learning performance has become a hot topic. Disagreement-based semi-supervised learning is an interesting paradigm, where multiple learners are trained for the task and the disagreements among the learners are exploited during the semi-supervised learning process. This survey article provides an introduction to research advances in this paradigm.
